comms_internal: The X argument is expressed twice: first as the (pronominal) clause-level direct object, and then once again as the canonical NP-internal possessor. Assaf: “The l- in case 1 is not optional. The following sentences would be ungrammatical: *qa-yuǧaˁ-u ġās-u Abrahām; *qa-yuǧaˁ-u ġās l-Abrahām; *qa-yuǧaˁ-u ġās Abrahām. The following might be, but I doubt anyone would say it: qa-yuǧaˁ ġās Abrahām”. Alternative is a construction where the X argument is extraposed (and unmarked), while the pronominal index still corresponds tot he DO_SBJ pattern: “Abrahām qa-yuǧaˁ-u ġās-u” [PN PRS-hurt.IPF.3MS-O.3MS head-POSS.3MS] ‘Abraham has a headache’. Technically, this is the EXT&DO_SBJ pattern.

Same as 38, same verb as 60, 100. Alternatives are i) a construction where the Y argument cannot be expressed: cit. form “mǝnšūl” “Abrahām mǝnšūl” [PN ill] ‘Abraham has the flu.’ and ii) “Abrahām ˁand-u našla” [PN by-O.3MS flu] ‘Abraham has the flu.’ with the EXT&3and_SBJ pattern.
Same as 114

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham took a book from the shelf.’

comms_internal: As follows from Assaf’s comments, this is not a transitive construction and object indexing is impossible (*Abrahām daxal-l-u l-əl-bet?).

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham is holding a book in his hand.’

comms_internal: Same verb as 21
Same verb as 19
Same as 43
This sentence can also be used in a metaphoric sense of ‘fight’.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier. Non-verbal predicate.
comms_internal: NK: “Just based on the fact that we know that sadiq is a noun. In this instance, technically, the pattern is indistinguishable from TR.” Alternative is a construction where X and Y are expressed as a coordinate NP: “Abrahām wu Maryam ṣǝdqān” [PN and PN friend.DU] ‘Abraham and Maryam are friends.’
Alternative is the construction without the “l-” preposition on the direct object: “Abrahām qlān-u s-samak” [PN fry.PF.3MS-O.3MS ART-fish] ‘Abraham fried the fish.’
Alternative is the construction with the “l-” preposition on the direct object: “Abrahām nsā-nu (lǝ-)ṭ-ṭarīq ǝl-lāx” [PN forget.PF.3MS-O.3MS to-ART-road ART-other]. This is a case of DOM.
This same verb can also be used in the TR pattern, as in the following example: “Abrahām ṣāḥ-a l-Maryam” [PN call.PF.3MS-O.3FS to-PN] ‘Abraham called Maryam.’

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham got to know Maryam a year ago.’
comms_internal: Same as 33
Same as 32

Same as 2, same as 60, 100. Alternative is a similar construction where the X argument is fronted (and unmarked) while still being marked by an index on the prepostion (sth. like the EXT&3and_SBJ pattern): “Abrahām ˁand-u sīyāra” [PN by-O.3MS car] ‘Abraham has a car.’

comms: This verb is probably related to the one in (39) but belongs to a different stem / conjugation class.

comms_internal: Lit. ‘Abraham, his house went on him’.

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham is trying to catch the cat.’
comms_internal: Same as 22. This same sentence can also mean ‘Abraham is holding the cat’.

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham is dreaming about a new car.’
comms_internal: Same as 97
Alternative is the construction without the “l-“ preposition (DOM marker): “Abrahām ġsal-u l-glāṣ” [PN wash.PF.3MS-O.3MS ART-glass] ‘Abraham washed the glass.’
Alternative is the construction without the “l-“ preposition (DOM marker): “Abrahām lbas-u l-panṭrūn māl-u”.

back_translation_en: ‘This device is called compass’, lit. ‘They call this a compass.’
comms_internal: Alternative (and probably even a more frequent alternative) is a construction with the X argument fronted (and unmarked): “hāyi l-āla ysǝmmū-ha bawṣala” [this.F ART-device call.IPF.3PL-O.3FS compass] ‘This device is called compass. (lit. they call it compass)’, sth. like a EXT&DO_BARE pattern.

DO indexes are not possible here (Assaf). Assaf’s explanation is that the reason for this is the fact that the verb “ntarsat” originally belonged to one of mediopassive stems. By the way, with a definite object (e.g. in a context like “The snow on the roof of the house melted. And the bucket downstairs filled with the water (i.e. the water from the melted snow).”) the construction used with the same verb is different, SBJ_b: “ǝṣ-ṣǝṭlīyyi ntarsǝt b-ǝl-ṃāy (mal-ǝl-ṯalǧ)” [ART-bucket fill.PF.3FS in-ART-water (POSS-ART-snow)] ‘The bucket filled with water (from the snow).’

Same as 119. Alternative (and probably a more neutral variant) is a construction where the X argument is fronted and unflagged (with sth. like the EXT&DO_SBJ pattern): “Abrahām tǝˁǧǝb-u hāyi lǝ-qmīṣ” [PN please.IPF.3FS-O.3MS this.F ART-shirt] ‘Abraham likes this shirt.’

This is a regular transitive pattern, as visible from a context with a definite Y argument (e.g. “Abraham’s firm did not pay him salary this month. He needs the money (that he is owed).”): “Abrahām mǝḥtāǧ-a l-ǝl-ᵊflūs (māl-u)” [PN need.PTCP.MS-O.3FS to-ART-money (POSS-O.3M)] ‘Abraham needs the money.’ Alternative to the transitive pattern is the SBJ_l pattern, as in the following example: “Abrahām mǝḥtāǧ lə-flūs” [PN need.PTCP.MS to-money].

Same verb as 2, 38, 100. Assaf: “dāyǝġ-ma-dāyǝġ is a preposition. The entire thing. Literally it means “around what (is) around”.” Alternatives are as follows: i) “l-ūlāyi mḥawṭa b-sūr” [ART-city surround.PTCP.FS in-wall] ‘The city is surrounded by a wall.’ (the pattern is b_SBJ) and ii) “sūr yḥǝwwǝṭ-a l-ūlāyi” [wall surround.IPF.3MS-O.3FS ART-city] ‘A wall surrounds the city.’

Alternative are constructions with verbs “fḏ̣l” (the actual form in the sentence would be “faḏ̣al”) or “ḏ̣ll” (ḏ̣all) and the same construction. Apart from this, it is possible to front the X argument, either keeping the flag (i) or dropping it (ii). (i) “l-Abrahām baqa/faḏ̣al/ḏ̣all ˁand-u ˁašǝġ yūro” [to-PN remain.PFV.3MS by-O.3MS ten euro] ‘Abraham has 10 euros left.’ (ii) “Abraham baqa/faḏ̣al/ḏ̣all ˁand-u ˁašǝġ yūro” [PN remain.PFV.3MS by-O.3MS ten euro] ‘Abraham has 10 euros left.’ The last option can probably be classified as an instance of the “EXT&3and_SBJ” pattern.
Alternative is the same construction without the “l-” preposition (DOM marker): “Abrahām ǧūwab-u ǝl-ᵊmˁallǝm”.

back_translation_en: ‘No, my shirt is different from yours.’
comms_internal: The same verb can also be used in the SBJ_3an pattern: “lā lǝ-qmīṣ māl-i tǝxtalǝf mǝn/ˁan māl-ak” [no ART-shirt POSS-1SG differ.IPF.3FS from/off POSS-2MS] ‘No, my shirt is different from yours.’ Two further options. (i) The copular variant with the verbal expression “kān” and the SBJ_metel pattern: “lā lǝ-qmīṣ māl-i mā mǝṯǝl māl-ak” [no ART-shirt POSS-1SG NEG like POSS-2MS] ‘No, my shirt is not like yours.’ (ii) The verb “šbh” with the TR pattern: “lā lǝ-qmīṣ māl-i mā tǝšbah-a lǝ-qmīṣ māl-ak” [no ART-shirt POSS-1SG NEG be_similar.IPF.3FS-O.3FS to-shirt POSS-2MS] ‘No, my short does not look like yours.’

comms: Not included in the database because this translation is semantically inaccurate.
comms_internal: This is basically identical to 89. Two further options have been proposed but cannot be included. (i) the verb “tˀxr”: “Abrahām tˀaxxar (b-ǝl-madrasa) mǝn-Maryam” [PN fall_behind.PF.3MS (in-ART-school) from-PN] ‘Abraham fell behind Maryam (in the school).’ This sentence features the SBJ_men pattern but has a metaphorical meaning. (ii) The verb “nḥṣġ”: “Abrahām nḥaṣaġ xalǝf-Maryam” [PN be_stuck.PF.3MS after-PN] ‘Abraham is stuck after Maryam’. This features the “SBJ_xalf” pattern but is also imprecise.
Alternative is the same construction without the “l-” preposition (DOM marker): “Abrahām qa-yǝḥrǝṯ-a ǝl-mazraˁa”.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier. Non-verbal predicate.

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham left the city he was born in.’

comms_internal: Same as 106
CV

back_translation_en: ‘The glass got stuck to the table.’

comms_internal: Alternative is the reversed transitive (DO_SBJ) construction with the verb “ġlb”: “Maryam ġǝlbǝt-u l-Abrahām” [PN defeat.PF.3FS-O.3MS to-PN] ‘Maryam defeated Abraham.’
Alternative is the construction with the verb “ǧāb” and the same transitive construction: “Maryam ǧābǝt walad” [PN bring.PF.3FS child] ‘Maryam gave birth to a child’.

comms: This verb is probably related to the one in (39) but belongs to a different stem / conjugation class.

comms_internal: Same as 92, 93
Same as 91, 93
Same as 91, 92
Same as 48

Same as 2, 38, 60. Alternative is another non-verbal construction with the “kān sǝˁr-” predicate: “hāḏa lǝ-gḷāṣ sǝˁr-u yūro wēḥǝd” [this.M ART-glass price-POSS.3MS euro one] ‘This glass costs one euro.’ This features the EXT_BARE pattern.
NK: “Inanimate plural objects agree with 3FS.”
Same as 79

CV. Assaf: “laˁǝb nafs is an idiom. Literally it means his soul is playing. In fact it means to be disgusted/squeamish by something. you can either treat it as one thing, or maybe translate tǝlˁab into ‘be squeamish’”.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: CV
Same as 7. The constuction with an indexed prepostion and a flagged NP co-exists with a more straightforward but less natural pattern (bī-Maryam).
Alternative is a construction with the same non-verbal predicate and the SBJ_wiya pattern: “Abrahām zǝˁlān wiya-Maryam” [PN angry with-PN] ‘Abraham is angry with Maryam.’

Same as 58. Alternative is a construction where the X argument is fronted and unflagged, so that we observe the EXT&DO_SBJ pattern: “Abrahām yǝˁǧǝb-u čāy” [PN please.IPF.3MS-O.3MS tea] ‘Abraham likes tea.’
NK. Optional qa- PRS marker is possible with the verb.
CV

Alternative is a construction with a CV “ṣāġ ˁaṣabi” and the same SBJ_3ala valency pattern: “Abrahām ṣāġ ˁaṣabi ˁala-ǝbn-u” [PN become.PF.3MS upset on-son-POSS.3MS] ‘Abraham became upset about his son.’

back_translation_en: ‘Abraham is getting irritated at his daughter.’
comms_internal: CV

Alternative is the construction where the X argument is fronted and unflagged: “Abrahām tǝˁǧǝb-u Maryam” [PN please.IPF.3FS-O.3MS PN] ‘Abraham is fond of Maryam.’ (this is in a sense a case of a “EXT&DO_SBJ” pattern).
